EFFECTIVE DATE: February 20, 2003



DEAL NO.: 187912


* * * * * * * * * * * * * * TRANSACTION SUMMARY * * * * * * * * * * * * * *


Deal Type:

Divestiture

Transaction Type:

Divestiture

Purpose:

Horizontal

Closing Date:

February 20, 2003

Deal Description:

Solectron Corp acquired the Global Asset Recovery operations of International Business Machines for an undisclosed price. The acquisition will strengthen the asset-recovery capabilities of Solectron Corp in its Global Services business unit. In addition, Solectron Corp will use the existing International Business Machines center in Raleigh, and acquire the related building, equipment and fixed assets. Solectron will also offer positions to the approximately 250 International Business Machines employees who support these operations.

Percent Sought:

100.000%

Terms:

Not disclosed

TARGET: Global Value Services 
BUYER: International Business Machines Corp. / International Business Machines Italia 
SELLER: Fiat SpA



LAST UPDATE: May 13, 2010 
ANNOUNCE DATE: June 29, 2005 
EFFECTIVE DATE: July 12, 2005



DEAL NO.: 344185


* * * * * * * * * * * * * * TRANSACTION SUMMARY * * * * * * * * * * * * * *


Deal Type:

Divestiture

Transaction Type:

Divestiture

Purpose:

Horizontal

Closing Date:

July 12, 2005

Deal Description:

IBM Italia, a subsidiary of IBM Corp, acquired Global Value Services from Fiat SpA for an undisclosed amount. Concurrent with the transaction, IBM Italia acquired the remaining 50% stake in its joint-venture, Global Value. Global Value Services works in the field of projection, development and management of information technology networks, while Global Value is marketing and distributing the products of Global Value Services, mainly in Italy. Global Value is a 50-50 joint venture between IBM Corp and Fiat SpA. The joint venture was created in June 2001 by the two companies in order to provide information technology services to companies. On 12 July 2005, the Italian Antitrust Authority approved the acquisition.

Percent Sought:

100.000%

Terms:

Not disclosed

TARGET: Green Pasture Software Inc 
BUYER: IBM Corp. 
SELLER: Green Pasture Software Inc



LAST UPDATE: December 17, 2003 
ANNOUNCE DATE: December 17, 2003 
EFFECTIVE DATE: December 17, 2003



DEAL NO.: 244232


* * * * * * * * * * * * * * TRANSACTION SUMMARY * * * * * * * * * * * * * *


Deal Type:

Acquisition

Transaction Type:

Acquisition of Private Company

Purpose:

Horizontal

Closing Date:

December 17, 2003

Deal Description:

International Business Machines Corp acquired Green Pasture Software Inc for an undisclosed amount. Green Pasture Software develops web-based products designed to optimize enterprise repositories, such as DB2 Content Manager, FileNET Panagon, or Domino.Doc, for electronic document management. The acquisition will expand the line of software products of International Business Machines that help manage documents. The software of Green Pasture is compatible with the DB2 database software of International Business Machines. The acquisition is the second for International Business Machines in 2003 in the area of content management.

Percent Sought:

100.000%

Terms:

Not disclosed

TARGET: Schlumberger Business Continuity Services 
BUYER: IBM Corp. 
SELLER: Schlumberger Ltd.



LAST UPDATE: July 2, 2004 
ANNOUNCE DATE: April 13, 2004 
EFFECTIVE DATE: May 6, 2004



DEAL NO.: 274442


* * * * * * * * * * * * * * TRANSACTION SUMMARY * * * * * * * * * * * * * *


Deal Type:

Divestiture

Transaction Type:

Divestiture

Purpose:

Horizontal

Closing Date:

May 6, 2004

Deal Description:

International Business Machines Corp acquired Schlumberger Business Continuity Services from Schlumberger Ltd for an undisclosed amount. The acquisition is aimed at increasing International Business Machines capabilities in helping clients ensure business continuity and providing Information Technology infrastructure and data recovery services. Schlumberger Business Continuity Services is headquartered in London, England. The transaction includes Schlumberger Business Continuity Services in Europe and in the US. International Business Machines plans to integrate Schlumberger Business Continuity Services into its subsidiary, IBM Global Services. International Business Machines plans to retain more than 260 employees from Schlumberger Business Continuity Services.

Percent Sought:

100.000%

Terms:

Not disclosed

LAST UPDATE: September 13, 2010 
ANNOUNCE DATE: January 25, 2007 
EFFECTIVE DATE: June 4, 2007



DEAL NO.: 408349


* * * * * * * * * * * * * * TRANSACTION SUMMARY * * * * * * * * * * * * * *


Deal Type:

Divestiture

Transaction Type:

Divestiture - Assets Acquired

Purpose:

Financial

Closing Date:

June 4, 2007

Source of Funds:

Cash

Deal Description:

IBM Corp and Ricoh Co formed a joint venture company based on the assets of IBM's Printing Systems Division-, of which 51% will be initially acquired by Ricoh in exchange for US$725.0 million in cash, including a management fee of US$35 million and the remaining 49% acquired over the next three years. The business generated approximately US$1.0 billion of revenue in 2006. The total pre-tax gain anticipated by IBM on the transaction will be between US$175 million and US$275 million and between US$100 million and US$150 million after closing. Following the closing of the initial transaction which is expected to be completed in the second quarter of 2007, IBM's Printing Systems Division will be called InfoPrint Solutions Co and will offer output solutions for enterprise printing. The Company begins operations with 1,200 employees headquartered in Boulder, Colorado and headed by Tony Romero, the general manager of IBM's Printing Systems Division.

Deal Type:

Divestiture

Transaction Type:

Purpose:

Horizontal

Closing Date:

August 1, 2012

Deal Description:

Toshiba Tec Corp, a subsidiary of TOSHIBA Corp, acquired the point-of-sale terminal business of IBM Corp for approximately US$850 million. The acquisition was initially a rumor transaction for US$870 million. The transaction is believed to strengthen TOSHIBA Corp's cloud computing services. The acquisition was subject to regulatory and customary closing conditions and was expected to close by the third quarter of 2012. Based in the United States, the point-of-sale terminal business of IBM Corp sells point-of-sale terminals. On June 29, 2012, the deal received approval from the European Union's antitrust body. On August 1, 2012, Toshiba Tec announced its initial closing of the acquisition.

TARGET: Kymata 
BUYER: IBM Corp. 
SELLER: Kymata



LAST UPDATE: February 3, 2003 
ANNOUNCE DATE: November 1, 2000 
EFFECTIVE DATE: November 1, 2000



DEAL NO.: 134217


* * * * * * * * * * * * * * TRANSACTION SUMMARY * * * * * * * * * * * * * *


Deal Type:

Divestiture Minority Interest

Transaction Type:

Divestiture

Purpose:

Horizontal

Closing Date:

November 1, 2000

Deal Description:

International Business Machines Corp and Kymata Ltd announced a multi year agreement to produce next generation optical networking chips for high speed e-business applications. As part of the agreement IBM acquired a 3% minority stake in Kymata Ltd. Under the terms of the agreement IBM and Kymata will jointly develop innovative optical chips used to help networking gear drive data and information at higher speeds across optical networks. The products will be designed around IBMs unique siliconoxynitride (SiON) process technology. SiON applies high volume semiconductor manufacturing techniques to optical chip making for the first time, to yield cost/performance advantages which can extend the use of optics in voice and data networks.

Percent Sought:

3.000%

Terms:

Not disclosed

* * * * * * * * * * * * * * TRANSACTION SUMMARY * * * * * * * * * * * * * *


Deal Type:

Divestiture

Transaction Type:

Divestiture

Purpose:

Horizontal

Closing Date:

June 21, 2000

Deal Description:

Philips Semiconductors, a unit of Koninklijke Philips Electronics NV (Royal Philips Electronics NV), Eindhoven, Netherlands, the manufacturer of electronic and electrical household goods, acquired the MiCRUS Semiconductor operation, an 8 wafer fabrication plant in East Fishkill, New York, US, from International Business Machines (IBM). The fabrication plant, which was orginally a joint venture between IBM and Cirrus Logic and later purchased by IBM, produces up to 250,000 wafers per year. Under the terms of a supply agreement, Philips Semiconductors will continue to supply products to IBM from the plant through 2002. Terms were not disclosed.

* * * * * * * * * * * * * * TRANSACTION SUMMARY * * * * * * * * * * * * * *


Deal Type:

Divestiture

Transaction Type:

Divestiture

Purpose:

Horizontal

Closing Date:

January 1, 2000

Deal Description:

Celestica Inc, acquired three assembly operations in Rochester, Minnesota, USA, Vimercate and Santa Palomba, Italy, from International Business Machines Corp for US$500m (GB309.63m pounds sterling). The Rochester location is involved in providing printed circuit board assembly and test services, while the combined Italian operations provide printed circuit board assembly and system assembly service. As part of the deal, Celestica Inc also agreed to provide a complete range of manufacturing services to IBM. The acquisition included the licensing of IBM intellectual properety rights for the manufacturing processes.

* * * * * * * * * * * * * * TRANSACTION SUMMARY * * * * * * * * * * * * * *


Deal Type:

Acquisition

Transaction Type:

Acquisition of non-US (foreign) company

Purpose:

Horizontal

Closing Date:

September 5, 2003

Deal Description:

IBM Australia Ltd, a subsidiary of International Business Machines Corp, acquired an additional 23% in IBM Global Services Australia Ltd from Lend Lease Corp for AUD160 million (US$ 104.5 million), of which AUD 80 million (US$52.2 million) was paid upon completion and the rest will be paid 12 months from completion. IBM Global Services Australia Ltd is a joint venture between IBM Australia, Lend Lease and Telstra Corp Ltd. In a related but separate transaction, IBM Australia also acquired the remaining 22.6% in the target company from Telstra for AUD153.5 million (US$100.2 million) in order to take full ownership of the company. Management of IBM Australia also intends to integrate its two consulting organizations, BCS and BIS, with IBM Global Services Australia to create a combined IBM Business Consulting Services the largest business consulting practice in Australia. IBM Global Services Australian employs over 8,000 people and has a 15% market share in the Australian IT services market.

* * * * * * * * * * * * * * TRANSACTION SUMMARY * * * * * * * * * * * * * *


Deal Type:

Acquisition

Transaction Type:

Acquisition of Private Company

Purpose:

Horizontal

Closing Date:

October 7, 2004

Deal Description:

International Business Machines Corp (IBM) acquired a content management company located in Charlotte, North Carolina, called Venetica Corp, for an undisclosed amount. One of the acquisition's purposes is to improve both companies' operational efficiencies, productivity, and to provide better customer service, according to general manager of IBM Data Management Software, Janet Perna. IBM plans to combine the operations of Venetica and Armonk, IBM's information management software business. The software of Venetica that they also plan to integrate into IBM's DB2 Information Integrator software, is compatible with IBM or non IBM data software, like Documentum, FileNet, Hummingbird, Interwoven, Open Text, and Stellent. Venetica provides software that enable institutions to access information.

DEAL NO.: 315892


* * * * * * * * * * * * * * TRANSACTION SUMMARY * * * * * * * * * * * * * *


Deal Type:

Acquisition

Transaction Type:

Acquisition of non-US (foreign) company

Purpose:

Horizontal

Closing Date:

November 19, 2004

Deal Description:

International Business Machines Corp (IBM), a public technology and software company, acquired Systemcorp ALG Ltd (Systemcorp) in Montreal, Canada, for an undisclosed amount. Systemcorp is known as the leader in providing Project Portfolio Management software and Web-based PMOffice used to track budgets, risks, and project deliverables. The acquisition will integrate the operations of Systemcorp into IBM's Rational Software development operations to develop advanced solutions to meet consumer demands, and deliver service to consumers to help complete IT projects including software development to large-scale systems integration. According to industry estimates, companies have invested over US$120 million per year in IT projects that they have difficulty managing with only less than 75% performance satisfaction. To develop more comprehensive tools and user-friendly solutions that deliver 100% of the benefit to consumers is one of the reasons of IBM's acquisition of Systemcorp.

Percent Sought:

100.000%

Not disclosed

Deal Type:

Divestiture

Transaction Type:

Divestiture

Purpose:

Horizontal

Closing Date:

December 31, 2002

Source of Funds:

Cash

Deal Description:

Hitachi Ltd acquired the computer hard disk drive business of International Business Machines Corp for $2.05 billion in cash, payable over three years during which time the two companies will run a joint venture. Hitachi will initially own 70% of the new company and will make a series of fixed payments to IBM before assuming full ownership after three years. The new organization will bring together approximately 24,000 employees, about 18,000 from IBM and 6,000 from Hitachi, with major manufacturing operations at 11 locations around the world.

TARGET: Isogon Corp.

SELLER: Isogon Corp.



LAST UPDATE: July 27, 2005 
ANNOUNCE DATE: June 16, 2005 
EFFECTIVE DATE: July 27, 2005



DEAL NO.: 340478


* * * * * * * * * * * * * * TRANSACTION SUMMARY * * * * * * * * * * * * * *


Deal Type:

Acquisition

Transaction Type:

Acquisition of Private Company

Purpose:

Horizontal

Closing Date:

July 27, 2005

Deal Description:

International Business Machines Corp (IBM), a developer of software and information technology products, acquired Isogon Corp, a private company that develops software products, for an undisclosed amount. A statement made by an IBM representative in an undisclosed press release says that the acquisition taps into a growing demand for management and automated software that handles expenditures and usage. The transaction is subject to regulatory approvals. Isogon will continue to operate as part of IBM's Tivoli Infrastructure-Management-Software business. Isogon is known for developing software products used to track inventory and usage of software applications.

Percent Sought:

100.000%

Terms:

Not disclosed
